verses.text: In the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah the son of Josiah, king of Judah, this word came to Jeremiah from the LORD:
verses.comment: Some Hebrew manuscripts read 'Jehoiakim' instead of 'Zedekiah.' The MT and context favor Zedekiah, who was the last king before exile.

verses.text: The LORD said to me: Make for yourself bonds and yokes, and put them on your neck,
verses.comment: The yoke symbolizes submission to foreign rule, foreshadowing exile and calling to humble obedience (see Jer. 28:10).

verses.text: and send them to the king of Edom, the king of Moab, the king of the Ammonites, the king of Tyre, and the king of Sidon, by the hand of the messengers who have come to Jerusalem to Zedekiah king of Judah.
verses.comment: The five kingdoms represent the regional powers surrounding Judah; God addresses the broader region, not just His people.

verses.text: Give them a message for their masters: ‘The LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, says this: Tell your masters:
verses.comment: The LORD’s supremacy is proclaimed even to foreign nations. His rule is not limited to Israel.

verses.text: It is I who made the earth, mankind, and the animals that are on the face of the earth by my great power and my outstretched arm; and I give them to whomever it seems right to me.
verses.comment: Affirms God's absolute authority as Creator. This echoes Genesis 1 and Psalm 24.

verses.text: Now I have handed over all these lands to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, my servant. I have even given him the wild animals to serve him.
verses.comment: 'My servant' shows God uses even foreign rulers for His purpose. This anticipates prophetic fulfillment and typology, such as God’s rule above all earthly kings.

verses.text: All nations shall serve him, his son, and his grandson, until the time for his land comes; then many nations and great kings will make him their slave.
verses.comment: There's an appointed time to Babylon’s rule, foreshadowing God's sovereignty over history and eventual reversal.

verses.text: But if any nation or kingdom will not serve Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and will not put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, I will punish that nation with the sword, famine, and plague, declares the LORD, until I have finished them by his hand.
verses.comment: Submitting to God's chosen means is necessary for survival, highlighting the theme of obedience, seen in later Christological submission.

verses.text: Therefore, do not listen to your prophets, diviners, dreamers, soothsayers, or sorcerers who say to you, ‘You shall not serve the king of Babylon.’
verses.comment: Deceptive spiritual leaders are contrasted with true prophecy. The need for authentic authority is a theme throughout Scripture.

verses.text: For they are prophesying lies to you, to remove you far from your land; I will drive you out, and you will perish.
verses.comment: False prophets bring judgement. Discernment of true teaching and tradition is necessary for spiritual survival.

verses.text: But the nation that brings its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serves him, I will let remain in its own land, to till it and dwell there, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Submission to God's providence leads to preservation, prefiguring the call to humble obedience in the New Covenant.

verses.text: I spoke to Zedekiah king of Judah in the same way, saying, ‘Bring your necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon, and serve him and his people, and live.
verses.comment: Jeremiah calls for submission, not rebellion, as a sign of trust in God’s plan despite apparent defeat.

verses.text: Why will you die, you and your people, by the sword, famine, and plague, as the LORD has spoken concerning any nation that will not serve the king of Babylon?
verses.comment: Refusal to obey brings death and exile. This is a call to repentance and obedience, which foreshadows salvation history.

verses.text: Do not listen to the words of the prophets who say to you, ‘You shall not serve the king of Babylon,’ for they are prophesying a lie to you.
verses.comment: Again, Jeremiah repeats the danger of false teaching; only the true revealed message preserves life.

verses.text: For I have not sent them, declares the LORD, but they prophesy falsely in my name, so that I may drive you out, and you will perish, you and the prophets who prophesy to you.
verses.comment: True authority is based on divine commissioning. This underscores the importance of apostolic foundation later in the New Testament.

verses.text: I also spoke to the priests and to all this people, saying, ‘This is what the LORD says: Do not listen to the words of your prophets who are prophesying to you, saying, “The vessels of the LORD’s house will soon be brought back from Babylon,” for they are prophesying a lie to you.
verses.comment: The restoration of sacred vessels is falsely promised by the deceivers. Emphasizes faithfulness rather than wishful thinking.

verses.text: Do not listen to them; serve the king of Babylon and live. Why should this city become a ruin?
verses.comment: Choosing obedience even when it means humiliation averts destruction, paralleling the call to take up the cross.

verses.text: But if they are prophets, and if the word of the LORD is with them, let them intercede with the LORD of hosts, that the vessels left in the LORD’s house, in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem may not go to Babylon.
verses.comment: Authentic prophets intercede, showing the value of mediatorship in prayer, a theme fulfilled in the New Testament.

verses.text: For this is what the LORD of hosts says concerning the pillars, the sea, the stands, and the rest of the vessels that still remain in this city,
verses.comment: Lists items left from Solomon’s Temple. This reflects the continuity of sacred tradition and the importance of material means in worship.

verses.text: which Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon did not take when he carried away Jeconiah the son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon, along with all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem—
verses.comment: A historical reminder of the first deportation, connecting past and present judgments.

verses.text: yes, this is what the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, says about the vessels remaining in the house of the LORD, the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem:
verses.comment: The repeated mention of vessels underscores their sacred function and the gravity of defilement and exile.

verses.text: ‘They will be carried to Babylon and will remain there until the day that I visit them,’ declares the LORD. ‘Then I will bring them up and restore them to this place.’
verses.comment: God promises eventual restoration, foreshadowing return from exile. The theme of restoration through authoritative leadership finds fulfillment in salvation history.
